src_text: A szafari kifejezés a populáris használatban a szárazföldi utazásokra utal, melynek célja a lenyűgöző afrikai vadon állatainak megtekintése, különösen a szavannán.
ref_text: The term safari in popular use refers to overland travel to view the stunning African wildlife, particularly on savanna.
hyp_text: In popular usage, safari means an overland journey, usually a trip by tourists in Africa. In Swahili, safari means "journey", originally from the Arabic meaning "a journey"; the verb for "to travel" in Swahili is kusafiri. These words are used for any type of journey, e.g. by bus from Nairobi to Mombasa or by ferry from Dar es Salaam to Unguja. Safari entered the English language at the end of the 1850s thanks to Richard Francis Burton, the famous explorer. The Regimental March of the King's African Rifles was 'Funga Safari', literally 'tie up the March', or, in other words, pack up equipment ready to march. In 1836 William Cornwallis Harris led an expedition purely to observe and record wildlife and landscapes by the expedition's members. Harris established the safari style of journey, starting with a not too strenuous rising at first light, an energetic day walking, an afternoon rest then concluding with a formal dinner and telling stories in the evening over drinks and tobacco. In the 1950s and 1960s Kenya, Tanzania, Uganda and Northern Rhodesia were still British colonies or protectorates. As a result, professional hunter was often a person born in the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland, or of an Anglo-African background. Most of them provided complete camping safari services for their clients. The largest and the best-known safari firms were White Hunters Limited (founded in the 1920s by Alan Black and Major Richard Cooper) and Ker & Downey (started in the 1940s by Donald Ker and Syd Downey). Professional hunter Donald Ker was featured in Hemingway's "The Short Happy Life of Francis Macomber" and Robert Ruark's "Horn of the Hunter"; Sydney Downey played a major role in another Hemingway's "The Green Hills of Africa". The regular clients of the 'White Hunters' were the wealthy, the royalty and the celebrities. A hunter's reputation was made by his ability to deliver a desired trophy to a client, preferably a big one, very quickly and without any physical exertion on the part of his client. The most extreme example of this safari style was Denis D. Lyell's silent gun. This .416 rifle was equipped with a special silencer that allowed the hunter to shoot an animal in its tracks and for the rest of his client's party to advance and start shooting without their quarry becoming aware of its danger. The gun saw the first major tests under fire on the safari that Theodore Roosevelt and his son Kermit went for in 1909. One of the first attempts of regulation of the safari business was with the 1900 Ordinance of the East African Protectorate. The first game laws were passed in British East Africa in 1896 and 1900, disabling people to kill, poison, snare, or capture any kind of game without a licence. With major hostilities ceased in 1945, wealthy sportsmen headed back to Africa. One of them was Ernest Hemingway. His 1953-54 safari was well documented in Ernest Hemingway on Safari and in the book by Philip Percival, who took the photos of the award winning 1937 movie, also called "Safari". During this period, the most famous safari firm was Ker & Downey. In the 1970s, the business started to decline due to an increase in poaching and restrictive laws by the African governments. Presently, the industry is regulated by the local government through Tanzania's wildlife division. In 1970, Kenya banned all hunting; the sport of big game hunting commandered the extensive government land to evolve into what is the largest safari industry in the world.
